headline.main: About Birth Control: Clearing Up Misconceptions About Contraception

docs.abstract: A group called Camfed is bringing lasting social change to African countries by educating hundreds of thousands of girls.
docs.snippet: A group called Camfed is bringing lasting social change to African countries by educating hundreds of thousands of girls.

headline.main: The Economic Impact of the Pill

docs.abstract: As economists look at the effect of contraception on the work force, one study found it accounted for 30 percent of the convergence of men's and women's earnings in a 10-year period.
docs.snippet: As economists look at the effect of contraception on the work force, one study found it accounted for 30 percent of the convergence of men's and women's earnings in a 10-year period.

headline.main: Tuesday Reading: Treating Preschool Cavities With Surgery

docs.abstract: Treating preschool cavities with surgery, a manifesto for air travelers, the student debt burden is growing and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: African-American women may process azithromycin at the same rate in pregnancy that they do otherwise, but that women of other races tend to metabolize the drug more slowly.

headline.seo: Antibiotic Dosage May Vary for Pregnant Women
headline.main: Regimens: Antibiotic Dosage May Vary in Pregnancy
headline.print_headline: Regimens: Antibiotic Dosage May Vary in Pregnancy

docs.abstract: James H Fischer study in journal Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy suggests that the correct dose of antibiotics in pregnancy may be different for African-Americans than for other women.
docs.snippet: African-American women may process azithromycin at the same rate in pregnancy that they do otherwise, but that women of other races tend to metabolize the drug more slowly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Because 25 to 30 percent of identical twins have separate placentas and amniotic sacs, they are sometimes misclassified as fraternal twins.

headline.seo: Study Finds Twins Can Easily Be Misclassified
headline.main: Childbirth: Identical or Fraternal? Not Always Clear
headline.print_headline: Childbirth: Identical or Fraternal? Not Always Clear

docs.abstract: British research study in journal BJOG suggests that many parents of twins are misinformed as to whether their babies are fraternal or identical because doctors themselves are confused; finds that 14.7 percent of couples involved had been misinformed about their babies.
docs.snippet: Because 25 to 30 percent of identical twins have separate placentas and amniotic sacs, they are sometimes misclassified as fraternal twins.

docs.abstract: A study measures how subsidizing pregnancy prevention programs and birth control might provide savings on publicly financed prenatal care and early-childhood benefits.
docs.snippet: A study measures how subsidizing pregnancy prevention programs and birth control might provide savings on publicly financed prenatal care and early-childhood benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past two decades, Rick Santorum has undergone a religious transformation that is now spurring a national conversation about faith in the public sphere.

headline.seo: Rick Santorum’s Journey From ‘Nominal Catholic’ to Clarion of Faith
headline.main: From ‘Nominal Catholic’ to Clarion of Faith
headline.print_headline: From ‘Nominal Catholic’ to Clarion of Faith

docs.abstract: Rick Santorum has undergone a religious transformation over the past two decades that is now spurring a national conversation about faith in the public sphere; once self-described as a 'nominal Catholic,' Santorum has become a deeply conservative Catholic who boldly invokes his faith while describing his policies on same-sex marriage, abortion and other social issues (Series: The Long Run).
docs.snippet: Over the past two decades, Rick Santorum has undergone a religious transformation that is now spurring a national conversation about faith in the public sphere.

byline.contributor: Sheryl Gay Stolberg reported from Great Falls, Va., and Laurie Goodstein from New York.
byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and LAURIE GOODSTEIN

docs.lead_paragraph: A new law in Texas requiring ultrasounds before an abortion comes close to state-sanctioned rape, and it’s emblematic of a broad assault on women’s reproductive rights at the state level.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column, prompted by a Texas law requiring vaginal ultrasound before an abortion, maintains that family planning and comprehensive sex education are a surer path to reducing the number of abortions than demeaning vulnerable women with state-sanctioned abuse and humiliation.
docs.snippet: A new law in Texas requiring ultrasounds before an abortion comes close to state-sanctioned rape, and it’s emblematic of a broad assault on women’s reproductive rights at the state level.

docs.lead_paragraph: Johanna and Marshall Kiev, featured in vows, Feb. 4, 2001, say they have grown to appreciate each other even more than they did when they first married.

headline.seo: Williams Syndrome, Their Child’s Disorder, Mobilized the Kievs
headline.main: A Fragile Child Brings Her Parents a Strong Marriage
headline.print_headline: A Fragile Child Brings Her Parents a Strong Marriage

docs.abstract: State of the Unions column looks back at the marriage of Johanna and Marshall Kiev, who were featured in the Vows column on Feb 4, 2001.
docs.snippet: Johanna and Marshall Kiev, featured in vows, Feb. 4, 2001, say they have grown to appreciate each other even more than they did when they first married.
